title: Photos of Major Taj Sareen who crashed over UK after 'ejecting too late' revealed
title_page: Photos of Major Taj Sareen who crashed over UK after 'ejecting too late' revealed | Daily Mail Online
text:
Waving to the camera before take off, these are the final photos of a heroic American pilot who died the day after they were taken.
Major Taj Sareen, 34, a father of one, died in a 'fireball' when his F/A-18 Hornet went down over UK farmland in October as he flying back to the U.S. after a six month long tour battling ISIS in the Middle East.
He is thought to have ejected later than he should have to avoid the jet crashing into nearby homes.

An amateur photographer took the pictures of Major Sareen on the runway at RAF Lakenheath in Suffolk the day before he died.
Matthew Varley, 23, said it was 'heart wrenching' to know they could be the pilot's final moments caught on camera.
He added: 'There were four aircraft on the day and he was the only pilot to take off his flight mask and actually wave which was quite poignant.
'When I later found out that it was possibly the last photo of him alive it became heart wrenching. He was smiling and looking happy and I think it's become a nice tribute to him.'
Major Sareen's family said they were 'thankful' after the last known photo of him emerged on an aviation enthusiast's website.
Major Sareen, from California, was flying one of six jets back to the U.S. from the Persian Gulf when it crashed in Redmere, Cambridgeshire.
He was branded a hero by farmer Peter Sizer who saw the crash. He told of how the pilot narrowly avoided two houses and crashed into farmland to avoid hurting anyone else.
An amateur photographer took these pictures of Major Sareen the day before his jet went down over UK farmland
His friend Preston Phillips, an ABC news anchor, said he was not surprised by the claims that he risked his life to risk harming others.
He said: 'I knew that was Taj. That's Taj in a heartbeat. I mean, he would do that to save people.'
Earlier, witnesses had told of the 300 to 400ft high fireball and 'unbelievable' bang that had occurred in the wake of the crash at around 10.30am.
Others spoke of seeing numerous emergency service personnel gathered around a parachute roughly 'a mile-and-a-half' from where the jet came down near the Cambridgeshire border.
Maj Sareen's friend Captain Annie Driscoll created a fund for his 16-month-old daughter Jade after his death and it has already raised nearly Â£50,000.
It has been reported that Maj Sareen's jet had refueling issues shortly before it crashed but officials could not confirm this.
